abstract: The companies say a global code of conduct will better protect online free speech and privacy against government intrusion.
snippet: The companies say a global code of conduct will better protect online free speech and privacy against government intrusion.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  Google, Microsoft and Yahoo and a group of human rights and public interest organizations plan to introduce Wednesday a global code of conduct that they say will better protect online free speech and privacy against government intrusion.

headline.main: Big Tech Companies Back Global Plan to Shield Online Speech
headline.print_headline: Big Tech Companies Back Global Plan to Shield Online Speech

byline.original: By Miguel Helft and John Markoff

abstract: The Internet search giant is increasingly looking to the energy sector as a potential business opportunity.
snippet: The Internet search giant is increasingly looking to the energy sector as a potential business opportunity.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  Google, the Internet search and advertising giant, is increasingly looking to the energy sector as a potential business opportunity.

headline.main: Google’s Green Agenda Could Pay Off

abstract: Google, the Internet search and advertising giant, is increasingly looking to the energy sector as a potential business opportunity, The New York Times’s Miguel Helft reported.
lead_paragraph: Google, the Internet search and advertising giant, is increasingly looking to the energy sector as a potential business opportunity, The New York Times’s Miguel Helft reported.

headline.main: Financial Aspect of Google’s Environmental Goals Grows

abstract: Google agreed to pay $125 million to settle two copyright lawsuits by book authors and publishers over its book-scanning project.
snippet: Google agreed to pay $125 million to settle two copyright lawsuits by book authors and publishers over its book-scanning project.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  Settling a legal battle, Google reached an agreement with book publishers and authors that clears the way for both sides to more easily profit from digital versions of printed books.

headline.print_headline: Google Strikes Deal To Allow Book Scans

byline.original: By Miguel Helft and Motoko Rich
